Name: Four Corners Resident Bear
About: After succumbing to rot in 2011, a 120 year-old red oak in Shorewood Hills' Four Corners Park was carved into a sculpture representing Wisconsin's native animals by Jamie Doeren. The sculpture was comissioned by the Village of Shorewood Hills following disagreement in the community over turning the tree into firewood.

Name: Shift
About: A series of steel panels perforated with patterns is attached to the concrete walls of the Highland Avenue underpass. LED fixtures behind the panels illuminate the previously dark underpass at night with a fantastic light display.

Name: Visible Bucky
About: As part of the "Bucky on Parade" public art event, 85 Bucky Badger statues by different artists were unveiled across Madison. This one is painted with Bucky's muscles and internal organs visible through his clothing, skin, and fur, and originally was displayed in front of Science Hall before being moved to its current location on the corner of Old University and Highland Avenues.

Name: Rachel in Mourning
About: Donated by the Knights of Columbus Catholic fraternal organization in memory of the victims of abortion in 2002. The sculpture faces a gravestone for the victims that was dedicated in October 1995.

Name: Untitled
About: A statue of an angel sitting with a bouquet of flowers in her hands.

Name: Joseph Our Patron
About: A statue of Saint Joseph, holding a hammer and carpenter's square, stands overlooking Resurrection Cemetery.

Name: Memorial to the Unborn Child II
About: A statue of a mother and father weeping before their unborn child, rendered in glass. The statue sits atop a granite columbarium pedestal where the remains of cremated unborn children are put in niches. A memorial brick walkway surrounds the statue.

Name: Anchorlily 2
About: A simple but elegant sculpture of a lilypad with an anchor for its roots welcomes visitors to Wingra Park. The sculpture was installed in 2018 along with the new park entrance.

Name: Jesus and the Children
About: Was installed sometime around or before 1965.

Name: The Rock
About: Unearthed in 1975, "The Rock" has gone on to become an outlet for Edgewood High School students, who paint messages on it for school events.

Name: Old Woman in a Shoe Slide
About: The slide, located on the playground at Vilas Park, has had many different appearances over the years, with the Madison Metropolitan School District and the Madison Art Museum's Art Cart program for children joining forces to repaint the exterior of the shoe.

Name: Annie C. Stewart Fountain
About: The fountain took seven years to build, and did not function as a fountain for much time after it was completed in 1925. It is known for its deteriorated state, with parts of the sculpture broken off and indiscernable. In 2016, the City of Madison began the process of refurbishing the fountain. When complete it will not function as a fountain. As of 2022, the project is still incomplete.

Name: The Badger
About: The sculpture was installed after the death of its artist, Ho-Chunk sculptor Harry Whitehorse.

Name: St. Joseph
About: The statue is located in the Sisters' Garden behind St. Mary's Hospital. St. Joseph was a favorite saint of Mother Odilia, the foundress of the order that built the hospital.

Name: Untitled
About: The sculpture was installed at the Jess Bullen Memorial Garden in memory of a 29 year-old car crash victim. The turtle sculptures refers to Jess's fondness of turtles.

Name: Madison Gateway
About: A large metal "M" stands at the border between Madison and Monona.

Name: Untitled
About: A seemingly abandoned or forgotten fountain or bird bath sits by the front wall of Olin-Turville Park.

Name: Untitled
About: A brick bench erected in honor of William Davison Stovall, M.D. Signs for businesses have been placed on top of the bench, making it rather unsightly.

Name: Fighting Wisconsin Badger
About: The statue was a gift from the National W Club in honor of the alumni athletic winners at the University of Wisconsin.

Name: The Ripple Effect
About: The sculpture marks the entrance to the Goodman Pool. It features bars of metal in a pattern that illustrates the rippling effect that can be found in water.

Name: Underflow
About: A metal sculpture in a fountain in front of Madison Water Utility.

Name: Alexa
Material: Metal, cast iron, enamel paint, concrete
About:
Local artist Susan Walsh states that the figure represents a worker. Its
 brightly colored parts of cast iron, steel aluminum, and enamel are 
giant replicas of "found" objects which might have come from the 19th 
century manufacturing firms across the street--a wire whisk, rotary 
disks, and a giant candlestick holder as a base. Walsh says Alexa might 
be the feminine for Alexander, a name suggesting power.

Name: Taking Flight
About: This sculpture symbolizes a bird taking flight into the world

Name: Chinese Fu Dog Lantern
About: Lofty cast concrete octagonal column supports a Chinese lantern, upon which resides the form of a Fu Dog.

Name: Tall White Lantern
About: Eight-sided hollow lantern of cast concrete, exhibiting sixteen rectangular windows, elevated by an octagonal column and topped by an octagonal lid. The entire work is painted white.

Name: Geometric Abstraction
About: Towering geometric abstraction of cast concrete positioned on a square base of the same material. The focal point of the sculpture is a round window that contains caulk and mortar vestiges, which suggest that perhaps a round piece of glass, or a similar material, once resided there.

Name: Blue Lantern on Tripod
About: Towering lantern painted blue, having, as its main component, a large hollow circular form with four holes, topped with a multi-sided lid from which protrudes a fanciful shape culminating in a ball.

Name: Creature Abstract Head
About: Cast concrete whitewashed head and torso mounted upon two cement blocks. The head is of an inverted teardrop in profile with a circular hole through the upper area, acting as the eyes of the figure, and a carved out rectangle to symbolize the mouth. THe torso with its left arm on the hip, is not in profile, giving the work a contorted look.

Name: Blue Urn With Dragon
About:
Large cast concrete urn painted blue with an oriental style dragon in 
red wrapped around it. A blue and red flower resides at the top acting 
as a lid.

Name: Smiling Mushroom
About: Large mushroom-shaped form resembling the face of a frog, having a pink stem, yellow face, and open red mouth complete with white teeth. The form is situated on a square of concrete base along with three small mushrooms, painted white.

Name: Polar Bear Chair
About: Polar bear situated in a seated position, painted white with highlights in red and black. The piece is a functioning chair.

Name: Easter Island Sculpture
About: Cast concrete imposing geometrically stylized human figure with generalized facial features and block-like body embracing a tablet on a shaft. The work was originally painted gold or copper.

Name: Mushrooms
About: Small cast concrete mushrooms of differing heights, presented as a group

Name: Dignified Figure with Tablet
About: Cast concrete imposing geometrically stylized human figure with generalized facial features and block-like body embracing a tablet on a shaft. The work was originally painted gold or copper.

Name: Layered Pyramid
About:
Cast concrete pagoda, painted white, consisting of many squares with 
slanted edges, decreasing in size from the base to the pyramidal point. 
Hollos slots formed by concrete risers, adding the the pyramidal effect,
 separate the squares.

Name: Tree Limb Faces
About: Distorted, elongated faces and bodies form twisting, branch-like forms, culminating in a phallic construction, topped by an orange monarch butterfly.

Name: Let the Great Spirits Soar (Effigy Tree)
About:
From a storm damaged Hackberry tree, / Honors his Indian Ancestors / and
 is a tribute to the effigy mound builders / sculpture funded by the 
City of Madison committee for the arts / Dane County Cultural Affairs 
Commission / and neighbors / Dedicated 5-19-91

Name: Sunbathers
About: This sculpture is three pieces working symbolically with each other. They are made of cut fractured limestone. The shape of each unit resembles abstract human bust forms. Both sides are carved with with the image of a reclining sunbather facing the lake. Installed on June 1, 1993.

Name: MG&E Solar Flower
About: This Sculpture also generate electricity

Name: Untitled
About: The sculpture is composed of two inter-connected limestone cylindrical stone forms. One side of each of the forms is faceted and the surfaces are incised with roughly parallel lines. The composite form sites at an angle on a smooth limestone rectangle and is held up with a rectangular Cot-Ten steel base.

Name: Spring
About: Custom made cast bronze sculpture of a tulip leaf design.

Name: Bronze Hosta Leaf
About: Custom made cast bronze sculpture of hosta leaf design

Name: Bud Forms
About: Given in memory of the artist by her children

Name: Stone Elephants
About: Two custom made, hand carved elephants from Thailand.

Name: Bronze Elephant
About: This Bronze Elephant symbolizes the special relationship between the University of Wisconsin-Madison, the City of Madison, and the UW Alumni in Thailand. Cast in Thailand for the Wisconsin Alumni Association-Thailand. Dedicated by Her Royal Highness Princess Maha Chakri Sirindhorn to Olbrich Botanical Gardens, 1/26/2007 Chitrlada Palace, Bangkok, Thailand.

Name: Stone Lions
About: Two custom made, hand carved lions from Thailand.

Name: Stone Sundial
About: Prairie-styled stone and bronze sundial with hand-carved native limestone top and bronze pointer. Bronze base mounted on concrete footing. Custom design and fabrication.

Name: Fiddleheads
About: Custom made, hand carved limestone sculpture of fiddlehead fern design. The sculpture depicts emerging ferns in the spring. There are five individual fernheads of height varying from four to twelve feet. Although they radiate from a central core at the base, they curve up and out from each other. Each fernhead has detailed carving on the topmost curving portion, which represents the coiled fernhead which has yet to open.

Name: Hippopotamus
About: Life sized, elongated hippo head of cast concrete painted pink, resting on the ground.

Name: Holstein Parade
About: This sculpture was created as part of the Cow Parade event in Wisconsin, 2006

Name: Cow
About: This sculpture was created as part of the Cow Parade event in Wisconsin, 2006

Name: Butterflies
About: Seven metal butterflies stand around the corner of Johnson and East Washington
